title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.0, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/0/ code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https:// www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: outlines propose change UMI4Cats. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.
code: ### Pull request process         *   Fork the package and clone onto your computer. If you haven't done this before, we recommend using `usethis::create_from_github("", fork = TRUE)`.

title: Contributing to UMI4Cats
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR.
code: *  We use [roxygen2](https://cran.r-project.org/package=roxygen2), with [Markdown syntax](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/roxygen2/vignettes/rd-formatting.html), for documentation.   *  We use [testthat](https://cran.r-project.org/package=testthat) for unit tests.  Contributions with test cases included are easier to accept.   ## Code of Conduct   Please note that the UMI4Cats project is released with a  [Contributor Code of Conduct](CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md). By contributing to this  project you agree to abide by its terms.

title: Getting help with SPICEY
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with SPICEY
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. See also Bioconductor help website. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !
code: *   If it's a question: start with [community.rstudio.com](https://community.rstudio.com/), and/or StackOverflow. If this a Bioconductor-related question, please ask it at the [Bioconductor Support Website](https://support.bioconductor.org/) using the [appropriate package tag](https://support.bioconductor.org/t/SPICEY) (the website will send an automatic email to the package authors). There are more people there to answer questions. Before opening a new issue, be sure to [search issues and pull requests](https://github.com//issues) to make sure the bug hasn't been reported and/or already fixed in the development version. ## What happens next?                                                                To be as efficient as possible, development of tidyverse packages tends to be very bursty, so you shouldn't worry if you don't get an immediate response.                                                               Typically we don't look at a repo until a sufficient quantity of issues accumulates, then there’s a burst of intense activity as we focus our efforts.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY R package designed infer cell type specificity single-cell omics data. supports input widely used frameworks Seurat (single-cell RNA-seq) Signac (single-cell ATAC-seq), computes metrics cell-type specificity regulatory transcriptional levels.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY designed operate results differential analyses performed either single-cell ATAC-seq (chromatin accessibility) single-cell RNA-seq (gene expression) data. analyses compare feature—either regulatory element (e.g., peak) gene—across cell types identify cell-type-specific activity expression. SPICEY takes advantage resulting statistics, specifically log2 fold-change associated adjusted p-values, reflect magnitude statistical confidence differential activity. leveraging pre-computed differential results, SPICEY quantifies cell-type specificity composite metrics capture strength selectivity feature enrichment individual cell types.

what: Cell-Type Specificity Indices: RETSI and GETSI
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY introduces two complementary metrics: RETSI (Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index): Quantifies cell-type specificity regulatory regions cell types (e.g., ATAC-seq peaks). GETSI (Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index): Quantifies specificity gene expression across distinct cell types. RETSI GETSI calculated using weighted specificity score feature (regulatory region gene), defined : TSIi,x=FCi,xmax(FC)x⋅wi,x TSI_{,x} = \frac{FC_{,x}}{\max(FC)_x} \cdot w_{,x} wi,x=rescale(−log10(padji,x),[0,1]) w_{,x} = \text{rescale}\left( -\log_{10}(padj_{,x}),\ [0, 1] \right) : ii specific cell type x∈{r,g}x \\{r, g\}, rr regulatory region (RETSI) gg gene (GETSI) FCi,x\text{FC}_{,x} log fold-change feature xx cell type ii wi,xw_{,x} weight term, defined rescaled value −log10(adjusted p-value)-\log_{10}(\text{adjusted } p\text{-value}) 0 1 Additionally, SPICEY supports integration regulatory elements putative target genes using multiple linking strategies, including: Nearest-gene assignment Co-accessibility-based linking (co-accessibility links available) linking approaches enable SPICEY combine regulatory specificity (RETSI) gene expression specificity (GETSI), facilitating integrated analyses gene regulatory architecture single-cell resolution. vignette demonstrates use SPICEY preprocessed GRanges input files. input files must prepared advance (provided package).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: complement fold change-based indices, SPICEY also quantifies distributional skewness features using Shannon entropy. regulatory region gene, activity expression values across NNN cell types converted probability distribution: H=−∑=1Npilog2(pi) H = - \sum_{=1}^{N} p_i \log_2(p_i) Hnorm=1−eH H_{norm} = 1 - e^{H} : pi,x=ai,x∑j=1Naj,xp_{,x} = \frac{a_{,x}}{\sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{j,x}} normalized activity expression feature xx across NN cell types ai,xa_{,x} activity (RETSI) expression (GETSI) value cell type $$ HxH_x Shannon entropy, Normalized Entropy ranges 0 (cell type specific) 1 (cell type shared).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Install development version GitHub:

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY requires carefully prepared input files representing processed single-cell omics data, specifically differential analyses chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq) /gene expression (RNA-seq). inputs provided within package must generated externally beforehand. detailed description required input necessary metadata.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Format: GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges Required columns: seqnames, start, end — genomic coordinates peak. avg_log2FC — average log2 fold-change chromatin accessibility peak specific cell type (output differential accessibility analysis). p_val — raw adjusted p-value corresponding differential accessibility test peak (output differential accessibility analysis). cell_type — cell type cluster label associated differential measurement. ATAC peaks input must include multiple rows per peak representing differential statistics cell type. example, peak may appear different avg_log2FC, p_val, cell_type values reflecting differential accessibility cell type.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Format: GRanges data.frame convertible GRanges Required columns: symbol — identifier gene. avg_log2FC — average log2 fold-change chromatin accessibility peak specific cell type (output differential accessibility analysis). p_val — raw adjusted p-value corresponding differential accessibility test peak (output differential accessibility analysis). cell_type — cell type cluster label associated differential measurement. RNA input must represent differential expression results, .e., statistics computed gene across cell types.

what: 3. Co-accessibility Links (optional, for region-to-gene linking mode)
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Purpose: link regulatory elements based co-accessibility inferred tools like Signac’s LinkPeaks(). supports integrative analysis regulatory elements gene expression. Format: Either GInteractions GRangesList object metadata columns. Required columns: Peaks1 — genomic coordinate ID first peak pair. Peaks2 — genomic coordinate ID second peak linked co-accessibility. coaccess — co-accessibility score correlation value. CCAN1, CCAN2 — CCAN (co-accessibility network) identifiers peaks. peaks referenced must match exactly ATAC peaks input (coordinates peak IDs).

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: section demonstrates run SPICEY using prepared input files, described earlier sections.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: calculate Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index (RETSI), following input required: atac : GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges containing differential accessibility results scATAC-seq data. Required columns: seqnames, start, end: Genomic coordinates peaks avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility peak p_val: Raw adjusted p-value differential accessibility tests cell_type: Cell type cluster label

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: calculate Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index (GETSI), required input : rna: GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges containing differential expression results scRNA-seq data. Required columns similar atac relevant gene expression. symbol — identifier gene. avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility peak p_val: Raw adjusted p-value differential accessibility tests cell_type: Cell type cluster label

what: Annotating Regulatory Elements to Target Genes
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY allows annotate regulatory elements putative target genes using one two methods:

previous_headings: Example: Run SPICEY step-by-step > Annotating Regulatory Elements to Target Genes
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: mode links regulatory region nearest gene TSS. Required inputs: retsi: Output spicey_retsi(), containing RETSI values annot_method: Set "nearest" txdb: TxDb object gene models annot_dbi: AnnotationDbi object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db) add gene metadata Optional parameters: filter_promoter_distal: Exclude promoter-proximal regions (default: TRUE) filter_protein_coding: Limit protein-coding genes (default: TRUE) keep_mito: Retain mitochondrial peaks (default: FALSE) add_tss_annotation: Include TSS distance related columns (default: FALSE) link_spicey_measures: Join RETSI GETSI scores gene (default: FALSE) verbose: Display progress (default: TRUE)
code: retsi_gene_nearest <- annotate_with_nearest(   retsi = retsi,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene::TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene,    annot_dbi = org.Hs.eg.db::org.Hs.eg.db )  head(retsi_gene_nearest) #>   seqnames     start       end width strand cell_type     p_val_adj p_val #> 1     chr7 142748901 142749963  1063      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 2    chr14  66378630  66379738  1109      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 3    chr22  27241597  27243500  1904      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 4    chr17  82909239  82910392  1154      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 5     chr2  79119834  79120951  1118      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 6    chr10 116587488 116588562  1075      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #>   avg_log2FC                    region RETSI norm_entropy distanceToTSS #> 1   6.025791  chr7:142748901-142749963     1  0.065607360             0 #> 2   5.742438   chr14:66378630-66379738     1  0.198069323         29965 #> 3   6.111680   chr22:27241597-27243500     1  0.007724027        546383 #> 4   6.066587   chr17:82909239-82910392     1  0.018789741             0 #> 5   6.160286    chr2:79119834-79120951     1  0.011755466             0 #> 6   6.299025 chr10:116587488-116588562     1  0.002236650             0 #>   nearestGeneSymbol annotation #> 1             PRSS1   Promoter #> 2           CCDC196     Distal #> 3               MN1     Distal #> 4              TBCD   Promoter #> 5             REG1A   Promoter #> 6          PNLIPRP1   Promoter

previous_headings: Example: Run SPICEY step-by-step > Annotating Regulatory Elements to Target Genes
title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: mode links regulatory regions genes via co-accessibility interactions, must computed externally (e.g., using Cicero Signac). Required inputs: retsi: Output spicey_retsi(), containing RETSI values annot_method: Set "coaccessibility" links: data.frame, GRangesList, Cicero/ArchR-style object co-accessibility links coaccess_cutoff_override: Minimum co-accessibility score (default: 0.25) Optional parameters: filter_promoter_distal: Exclude promoter-proximal regions (default: TRUE) filter_protein_coding: Limit protein-coding genes (default: TRUE) keep_mito: Retain mitochondrial peaks (default: FALSE) add_tss_annotation: Include TSS distance related columns (default: FALSE) link_spicey_measures: Join RETSI GETSI scores gene (default: FALSE) verbose: Display progress (default: TRUE)
code: # Filter links for high coaccessibility score coacc_links <- cicero_links |>    dplyr::filter(coaccess > 0.5)  retsi_gene_coacc <- annotate_with_coaccessibility(   links = coacc_links,   retsi = retsi,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene::TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene,    annot_dbi = org.Hs.eg.db::org.Hs.eg.db,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25   ) #> [1] "Coaccessibility cutoff used: 0.25"  head(retsi_gene_coacc) #>   seqnames     start       end width strand cell_type     p_val_adj p_val #> 1     chr7 142748901 142749963  1063      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 2    chr14  66378630  66379738  1109      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 3    chr22  27241597  27243500  1904      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 4    chr17  82909239  82910392  1154      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 5     chr2  79119834  79120951  1118      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 6    chr10 116587488 116588562  1075      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #>   avg_log2FC                    region RETSI norm_entropy distanceToTSS #> 1   6.025791  chr7:142748901-142749963     1  0.065607360             0 #> 2   5.742438   chr14:66378630-66379738     1  0.198069323         29965 #> 3   6.111680   chr22:27241597-27243500     1  0.007724027        546383 #> 4   6.066587   chr17:82909239-82910392     1  0.018789741             0 #> 5   6.160286    chr2:79119834-79120951     1  0.011755466             0 #> 6   6.299025 chr10:116587488-116588562     1  0.002236650             0 #>   annotation gene_coacc in_TSS TSS_gene #> 1   Promoter         NA  FALSE     <NA> #> 2     Distal         NA  FALSE     <NA> #> 3     Distal         NA  FALSE     <NA> #> 4   Promoter         NA  FALSE     <NA> #> 5   Promoter         NA   TRUE    REG1A #> 6   Promoter         NA  FALSE     <NA>

text: retsi_gene_coacc: Output annotate_with_coaccessibility(), linking peaks co-accessible genes RETSI scores getsi: Output spicey_getsi(), providing GETSI scores genes integrating RETSI GETSI, SPICEY enables comprehensive analysis tissue-specific regulatory logic epigenetic transcriptional levels.
code: spicey_coacc <- link_spicey_coaccessible(retsi_gene_coacc, getsi) head(spicey_coacc) #>   seqnames start end width strand cell_type p_val_adj p_val avg_log2FC region #> 1     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 2     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 3     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 4     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 5     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 6     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #>   RETSI RETSI_entropy distanceToTSS annotation gene_coacc in_TSS TSS_gene #> 1    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      REG1A     NA     <NA> #> 2    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PRSS1     NA     <NA> #> 3    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PNLIP     NA     <NA> #> 4    NA            NA            NA       <NA>    ANKRD62     NA     <NA> #> 5    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PRSS2     NA     <NA> #> 6    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PTF1A     NA     <NA> #>       GETSI GETSI_entropy #> 1 1.0000000   0.004473985 #> 2 1.0000000   0.095847822 #> 3 0.9528626   0.013732911 #> 4 0.8639239   0.024782578 #> 5 0.8493565   0.376959946 #> 6 0.8054632   0.011539343

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: SPICEY provides modular functions—spicey_retsi(), spicey_getsi(), annotate_with_nearest()—users prefer fine-grained control, also includes wrapper function, run_spicey(), streamlines full workflow single, reproducible step. wrapper automatically determines operations perform based input data parameters provided, making ideal users seeking quick, end--end analysis without manually managing intermediate step. supplied differential accessibility (ATAC) /gene expression (RNA) data, gene-linking strategy (“nearest” “coaccessibility”), run_spicey() performs following operations needed: RETSI computation (ATAC data provided) GETSI computation (RNA data provided) Annotation regulatory regions target genes, via: "nearest" gene TSS "coaccessibility" links (e.g., Cicero ArchR) Linking RETSI GETSI scores gene (link_spicey_measures = TRUE) function returns structured list containing intermediate final outputs, making easy inspect reuse individual components pipeline. users prefer run step independently—example, apply custom filters transformations—module remains fully accessible can run separately.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: Depending inputs provided, run_spicey() performs: RETSI calculation – differential accessibility data (ATAC-seq) GETSI calculation – differential expression data (RNA-seq) Annotation regulatory regions genes (optional): "nearest": Assign closest gene "coaccessibility": Use user-supplied co-accessibility links Linking RETSI GETSI scores gene (optional)

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: atac: GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges, containing scATAC-seq differential accessibility results. Required columns: seqnames, start, end: Genomic coordinates avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility p_val: Raw adjusted p-value DA analysis cell_type: Cell type cluster label rna: GRanges object data frame convertible GRanges, containing scRNA-seq differential expression results. structure atac: symbol — identifier gene. avg_log2FC: Average log2 fold-change accessibility p_val: Raw adjusted p-value DA analysis cell_type: Cell type cluster label annot_method: One "nearest" (default) "coaccessibility", indicating method link peaks genes. links: Required annot_method = "coaccessibility". data.frame, GRangesList, Cicero/ArchR-style object co-accessibility links (peak-pairs scores). coaccess_cutoff_override: (default = 0.25) Minimum co-accessibility score retain link. filter_promoter_distal: (default = TRUE) Whether exclude promoter-proximal interactions using co-accessibility. filter_protein_coding: (default = TRUE) Whether restrict gene annotations protein-coding genes. txdb: TxDb object gene models used annotation. annot_dbi: AnnotationDbi object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db) adding gene symbols additional metadata. keep_mito: (default = FALSE) Whether retain mitochondrial peaks. add_tss_annotation: (default = FALSE) Whether include TSS-related metadata (e.g., distance TSS) output. link_spicey_measures: (default = FALSE) Whether merge RETSI GETSI scores gene annotation. verbose: (default = TRUE) Whether display progress messages execution.
code: spicey_nearest <- run_spicey(   atac = atac,    rna = rna,    annot_method = "nearest",    txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene::TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene,    annot_dbi = org.Hs.eg.db::org.Hs.eg.db,   link_spicey_measures = TRUE ) head(spicey_nearest) #>   seqnames     start       end width strand cell_type     p_val_adj p_val #> 1     chr7 142748901 142749963  1063 chr2  79119834  79120951  1118      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 5    chr10 116587488 116588562  1075      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #> 6    chr10 116553223 116553959   737      *    Acinar 1.158316e-300     0 #>   avg_log2FC                    region RETSI RETSI_entropy distanceToTSS #> 1   6.025791  chr7:142748901-142749963     1   0.065607360             0 #> 2   6.111680   chr22:27241597-27243500     1   0.007724027        546383 #> 3   6.066587   chr17:82909239-82910392     1   0.018789741             0 #> 4   6.160286    chr2:79119834-79120951     1   0.011755466 GETSI GETSI_entropy #> 1        PRSS1   Promoter 1.0000000000   0.095847822 #> 2          MN1     Distal 0.0001055331   0.681930617 #> 3         TBCD   Promoter 0.0060596138   0.491472040 #> 4        REG1A   Promoter 1.0000000000   0.004473985 #> 5     PNLIPRP1   Promoter 0.7329113167   0.017352521 #> 6        PNLIP     Distal 0.9528625893   0.013732911  spicey_coacc <- run_spicey(   atac = atac, coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   link_spicey_measures = TRUE ) #> [1] "Coaccessibility cutoff used: 0.25" head(spicey_coacc) #>   seqnames start end width strand cell_type p_val_adj p_val avg_log2FC region #> 1     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 2     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 3     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 4     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA         NA   <NA> #> 5     <NA>    NA  NA    NA   <NA>    Acinar        NA    NA       <NA>      REG1A 1.0000000 #> 2    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PRSS1 1.0000000 #> 3    NA            NA            NA       <NA>      PNLIP 0.9528626 #> 4    NA            NA title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: following output data frame object containing genomic regions, representing regulatory element (e.g., enhancer promoter) annotated multiple metadata columns. columns provide statistical, biological, functional information derived chromatin accessibility gene expression data.

title: Measuring tissue specificity from single cell data with SPICEY
text: annotated GRanges object thus serves comprehensive resource combining genomic location, cell type-specific accessibility, gene linkage, expression specificity — facilitating downstream functional genomics analyses.

title: Authors and Citation

title: Authors and Citation
text: author1, author2, author3 (publicationYear) articleTitle, *journalName*; volumeNumber, [linkToPublication](linkToPublication)
code: @Article{,   entry = {Article},   title = {articleTitle},   author = {{author1} and {author2} and {author3}},   journal = {journalName},   year = {publicationYear},   volume = {volume},   number = {number},   pages = {pages},   url = {linkToPublication}, }

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: goal SPICEY provide user-friendly pipeline quantifying visualizing tissue specificity specificity

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: can install latest release SPICEY github repository: Now can load package using library(SPICEY).

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: detailed instructions use SPICEY, please see vignette.
code: library(SPICEY) # Compute GETSI  results <- run_spicey(rna = rna)  # Compute RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI results <- run_spicey(atac=atac, rna=rna)  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through nearest gene method result <- run_spicey(   atac = atac,    rna = rna,    annot_method = "nearest",    txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene,   annot_dbi = org.Hs.eg.db,   link_spicey_measures = TRUE )  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through coaccessibility method result <- run_spicey(   atac = atac,    rna = rna,    annot_method = "coaccessibility",   links = coaccess_links,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene )  # Compute GETSI + RETSI and link RE to target genes through coaccessibility method # and link both SPICEY measures result <- run_spicey(   atac = atac,    rna = rna,    link_spicey_measures = TRUE,   annot_method = "coaccessibility",   links = coaccess_links,   txdb = TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38.knownGene, )

title: Calculates cell type specificity from single cell data
text: Please note SPICEY project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project, agree abide terms.

what: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: Annotate co-accessible links CCAN membership return GInteractions

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
code: annotate_links_with_ccans(   links,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   tolerance_digits = 2,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE,   txdb = NULL )

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: links data.frame co-accessibility links columns Peak1, Peak2, coaccess. coaccess_cutoff_override Numeric, coaccessibility cutoff CCAN generation (default 0.25). tolerance_digits Integer, rounding precision cutoff (default 2). filter_promoter_distal Logical, whether keep Promoter-Distal links (default TRUE). txdb TxDb object peak annotation (required filter_promoter_distal=TRUE).

title: Annotate co-accessible links with CCAN membership and return GInteractions — annotate_links_with_ccans
text: GInteractions object annotated coaccess, CCAN1, CCAN2 metadata columns.

what: Annotate regulatory elements overlapping transcription start sites (TSS) — annotate_tss
title: Annotate regulatory elements overlapping transcription start sites (TSS) — annotate_tss
text: function identifies regulatory elements directly overlap annotated transcription start sites (TSS, defined 1 bp ranges) assigns corresponding gene symbols.

title: Annotate regulatory elements overlapping transcription start sites (TSS) — annotate_tss
Annotate regulatory elements overlapping transcription start sites (TSS) — annotate_tss
text: txdb TxDb object used extract gene coordinates. re GRanges object data.frame regulatory elements annotate. annot_dbi AnnotationDbi object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db) gene symbol mapping.

title: Annotate regulatory elements overlapping transcription start sites (TSS) — annotate_tss
text: data.frame regulatory elements annotated : in_TSS: Logical indicating whether element overlaps TSS. TSS_gene: Gene symbol overlapping TSS, .

what: Annotate Regulatory Elements with Gene Targets Using Co-Accessibility Links — annotate_with_coaccessibility
title: Annotate Regulatory Elements with Gene Targets Using Co-Accessibility Links — annotate_with_coaccessibility
text: function annotates regulatory elements (REs) putative gene targets integrating co-accessibility links include CCAN (co-accessibility networks) metadata. extracts promoter regions TxDb object, optionally filters protein-coding genes, links REs genes based chromatin co-accessibility. Optionally, REs overlapping transcription start site (TSS) can also annotated directly.

title: Annotate Regulatory Elements with Gene Targets Using Co-Accessibility Links — annotate_with_coaccessibility
code: annotate_with_coaccessibility(   links,   retsi,   txdb,   annot_dbi,   protein_coding_only = TRUE,   keep_mito = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE,   add_tss_annotation = TRUE )

title: Annotate Regulatory Elements with Gene Targets Using Co-Accessibility Links — annotate_with_coaccessibility
text: links GInteractions object representing co-accessibility links CCAN metadata. retsi GRanges data.frame object representing regulatory elements annotate. data.frame, must contain columns sufficient construct GRanges (e.g., seqnames, start, end). txdb TxDb object used extract promoter regions TSS annotations. annot_dbi AnnotationDbi annotation database object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db) mapping gene IDs gene symbols types. protein_coding_only Logical indicating whether restrict promoter regions protein-coding genes (default: TRUE). keep_mito Logical indicating whether keep mitochondrial (chrM/MT) chromosomes promoter extraction (default: FALSE). verbose Logical; TRUE, informative messages printed processing (default: TRUE). coaccess_cutoff_override Numeric; co-accessibility score cutoff override default filtering annotate_links_with_ccans (default: 0.25). filter_promoter_distal Logical; whether filter links retain promoter-distal interactions (default: TRUE). add_tss_annotation Logical; whether annotate regulatory elements overlapping TSS directly (default: TRUE).

title: Annotate Regulatory Elements with Gene Targets Using Co-Accessibility Links — annotate_with_coaccessibility
text: data.frame regulatory elements annotated : Distance nearest TSS promoter/distal classification Co-accessible gene targets Optional: TSS overlap TSS gene symbol

what: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest
title: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest
text: function uses ChIPseeker-like logic annotate peaks distance nearest TSS (transcription start site), classifies Promoter (<2kb) Distal, adds nearest gene ID using Biomart-annotated genes. Optionally, can annotate whether region overlaps TSS directly using 1-bp TSS coordinates.

title: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest
code: annotate_with_nearest(   retsi,   txdb,   annot_dbi,   protein_coding_only = TRUE,   keep_mito = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   add_tss_annotation = FALSE )

title: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest
text: retsi GRanges object data.frame containing regulatory elements annotate. txdb TxDb object used extract promoter regions. annot_dbi AnnotationDbi annotation database object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db) mapping gene IDs gene symbols types. protein_coding_only Logical indicating whether restrict promoter regions protein-coding genes (default: TRUE). keep_mito Logical indicating whether keep mitochondrial (chrM/MT) chromosomes promoter extraction (default: FALSE). verbose Logical; TRUE, informative messages printed processing (default: TRUE). add_tss_annotation Logical; whether also annotate whether region overlaps TSS (default: TRUE).

title: Annotate regions with nearest gene and promoter information — annotate_with_nearest
text: data.frame following columns: distanceToTSS: Distance nearest TSS annotation: Promoter/Distal classification based distance nearestGeneSymbol: Symbol nearest gene in_TSS (optional): Logical indicating RE overlaps TSS TSS_gene (optional): Gene symbol overlapping TSS original metadata

what: Get Promoter Regions with Optional Filtering for Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) from a TxDb object, optionally restricting to protein-coding genes and retaining only primary chromosomes (using a robust internal filter). Gene symbols and types are added using an AnnotationDbi object. — get_promoters
title: Get Promoter Regions with Optional Filtering for Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) from a TxDb object, optionally restricting to protein-coding genes and retaining only primary chromosomes (using a robust internal filter). Gene symbols and types are added using an AnnotationDbi object. — get_promoters
text: Get Promoter Regions Optional Filtering Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) TxDb object, optionally restricting protein-coding genes retaining primary chromosomes (using robust internal filter). Gene symbols types added using AnnotationDbi object.

title: Get Promoter Regions with Optional Filtering for Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) from a TxDb object, optionally restricting to protein-coding genes and retaining only primary chromosomes (using a robust internal filter). Gene symbols and types are added using an AnnotationDbi object. — get_promoters
code: get_promoters(   txdb,   annot_dbi,   keep_mito = FALSE,   protein_coding_only = TRUE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Get Promoter Regions with Optional Filtering for Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) from a TxDb object, optionally restricting to protein-coding genes and retaining only primary chromosomes (using a robust internal filter). Gene symbols and types are added using an AnnotationDbi object. — get_promoters
text: txdb TxDb object (e.g., GenomicFeatures::makeTxDbFromGFF() prebuilt TxDb package). annot_dbi AnnotationDbi object (e.g., org.Hs.eg.db, org.Mm.eg.db) mapping gene IDs symbols types. keep_mito Logical; whether keep mitochondrial chromosome (default = FALSE). protein_coding_only Logical; whether restrict protein-coding genes (default = TRUE). verbose Logical; print informative messages (default = TRUE).

title: Get Promoter Regions with Optional Filtering for Protein-Coding Genes Extracts promoter regions (±2kb default) from a TxDb object, optionally restricting to protein-coding genes and retaining only primary chromosomes (using a robust internal filter). Gene symbols and types are added using an AnnotationDbi object. — get_promoters
text: GRanges object promoter regions, annotated gene symbols, optionally filtered protein-coding genes.

what: Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible

text: function combines GETSI (Gene Expression Tissue Specificity Index) data RETSI (Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index) results, matching gene symbols cell types. renames entropy columns, performs joins merge relevant annotations, resolves coordinate conflicts.

title: Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
Link RETSI peaks with GETSI values from coaccessibility — link_spicey_coaccessible
text: getsi data.frame tibble containing GETSI results least columns: gene_id: gene gene_id cell_type GETSI norm_entropy seqnames, start, end re data.frame tibble containing RETSI results least columns: gene_coacc: gene symbols coaccessible gene region cell_type norm_entropy seqnames, start, end, annotation, distanceToTSS, region, RETSI

what: Compute RETSI scores for differential chromatin accessibility data — retsi
title: Compute RETSI scores for differential chromatin accessibility data — retsi
text: function calculates Regulatory Element Tissue Specificity Index (RETSI) list differential accessibility results (either GRanges data.frames).

title: Compute RETSI scores for differential chromatin accessibility data — retsi
Compute RETSI scores for differential chromatin accessibility data — retsi
text: atac_da named list element corresponds cell type contains either: GRanges object differential peaks metadata columns: avg_log2FC, p_val data.frame structure, including cell_type column

title: Compute RETSI scores for differential chromatin accessibility data — retsi
text: data.frame RETSI scores per region cell type. Includes columns: region, RETSI, supporting metadata.

what: Run the full SPICEY pipeline — run_spicey
title: Run the full SPICEY pipeline — run_spicey
text: function runs SPICEY pipeline compute tissue specificity scores single-cell ATAC-seq (RETSI) /RNA-seq (GETSI) data. optionally links regulatory elements genes using either nearest-gene co-accessibility based annotation, can combine RETSI GETSI values downstream integration.

title: Run the full SPICEY pipeline — run_spicey
code: run_spicey(   atac = NULL,   rna = NULL,   annot_method = NULL,   links = NULL,   link_spicey_measures = FALSE,   coaccess_cutoff_override = 0.25,   filter_promoter_distal = TRUE,   filter_protein_coding = TRUE,   txdb = NULL,   keep_mito = FALSE,   annot_dbi = NULL,   add_tss_annotation = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Run the full SPICEY pipeline — run_spicey
text: atac Seurat SummarizedExperiment object containing scATAC-seq data. rna Seurat SummarizedExperiment object containing scRNA-seq data. annot_method Method region--gene annotation: "nearest" "coaccessibility". links Co-accessibility links (e.g., Cicero ArchR) co-accessibility annotation. link_spicey_measures Logical; whether link RETSI GETSI via annotated genes. coaccess_cutoff_override Minimum co-accessibility score retain links (default: 0.25). filter_promoter_distal Logical; whether exclude promoter-proximal links (default: TRUE). filter_protein_coding Logical; whether filter protein-coding genes (default: TRUE). txdb TxDb object genomic annotations. keep_mito Logical; whether keep mitochondrial regions (default: FALSE). annot_dbi Optional AnnotationDbi object additional gene info (e.g., gene symbols). add_tss_annotation Logical; whether include TSS annotation columns output (default: FALSE). verbose Logical; whether print messages execution (default: TRUE).

title: Run the full SPICEY pipeline — run_spicey
text: tibble list containing RETSI, GETSI, /linked results depending input parameters.

what: Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi
title: Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi

title: Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi
Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi
text: rna_da named list Dataframe objects, typically one per cell type, containing RNA differential expression data columns avg_log2FC, p_val, gene_id, etc.

title: Compute GETSI scores and entropy from RNA-seq data — spicey_getsi
text: Dataframe object GETSI scores entropy values metadata columns.

what: Compute RETSI scores and entropy for scATAC-seq regulatory elements — spicey_retsi
title: Compute RETSI scores and entropy for scATAC-seq regulatory elements — spicey_retsi
text: wrapper function takes list per-cell-type differential accessibility results (GRanges data.frames), computes RETSI scores, adds normalized entropy score quantify cell-type specificity regulatory region.

title: Compute RETSI scores and entropy for scATAC-seq regulatory elements — spicey_retsi
Compute RETSI scores and entropy for scATAC-seq regulatory elements — spicey_retsi
text: atac_da named list GRanges data.frames (one per cell type), differential accessibility metrics including avg_log2FC p_val.

title: Compute RETSI scores and entropy for scATAC-seq regulatory elements — spicey_retsi
text: data.frame RETSI scores normalized entropy region, including region, cell_type, RETSI, norm_entropy.
